summary: The document is a memorandum from 4 May 1967, directed to the Director of Security, focusing on Edward P. Morgan, a former FBI agent. It outlines Morgan's post-FBI career, including his successful transition into private law practice, particularly in Federal Communications, and his role in the Office of Price Stabilization during the Korean War. The memo also explores Morgan's financial success, his contentious relationship with J. Edgar Hoover, and his social engagements in Washington, D.C., including his involvement with the Society of Former Agents of the FBI and exclusive clubs like the Touchdown Club.
key_findings: Edward P. Morgan transitioned from the FBI in 1947 to a prosperous career in private law practice, specializing in Federal Communications.
His tenure at the Office of Price Stabilization during the Korean War involved hiring former FBI agents at elevated salaries, creating friction with J. Edgar Hoover.
Morgan's bid for National President of the Society of Former Agents in 1957 failed, prompting his disengagement from the Society.
The memorandum comments on Morgan's affluent lifestyle, his memberships in prestigious clubs, and his influential network within the broadcasting and news sectors.
